course.subject: LANG
course.name: Technical Communication I
course.description: The course provides students with a broad introduction to English within the discipline of engineering. A central aim of the course is to encourage students to analyze critically the wider social implications of engineering products and processes, through the careful examination of texts (and other media) beyond their own specific engineering field and to communicate effectively by delivering oral presentations and writing reports on topics relevant to all engineers.
course.prerequisites: LANG 1403 OR LANG 1404 OR LANG 1003 (prior to 2022-23)

reviews.author: (â â—•â á´—â â—•â â )
reviews.comment_content: Mainly it talks about some of the ethical considerations about engineering and discusses some of the conflicts and dilemas that we may face as engineers in the future. The course discusses on some of the past engineering cases with ethical contradictions. The course also teaches you how to analyse the engineering ethics issues and solve the dilema by following some guildlines set by different institutions of different regions and countries. It also teaches you how to write a proposal for an innovative engineering idea.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching isn't too bad, the lecturer teaches using powerpoint and points out some of the main ideas. However the overall teaching style is similar to secondary school style though so it isn't too interesting.
reviews.comment_grading:
Analytical report on an engineering ethics problem, Individual (30%)
Group presentation on the same engineering ethics issue (20%)
Proposal report for an innovative engineering idea, Individual (30%)
Group presentation on the same innovative engineering idea (20%)
The comments received from the lecturer and the actual grades does not seem to be well proportioned so expect to get poor grades even if they say you did decent.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload, as long as you find normal groupmates and does your individual work on time then theres nothing much to do.

reviews.author: Mushroomjumper
reviews.title: Group Project + Bad Grading = Bad Grade
reviews.comment_content:
A group presentation and seminar discussion on an engineering ethics issue (group and individual)
30%

A group presentation of a proposal for an engineering innovation (group and
individual)

reviews.comment_teaching:
Can't say teaching is bad, it is just normal LANG lecturer.
Bruce is the course coordinator, he would teach using the powerpoint, putting screenshots on the powerpoint to teach. Quite boring tbh. Bruce really gave feedback on how to present after the first presentation, so I did better for the second presentation. (Multimodality: More than Good -> Very Good)
reviews.comment_grading:
The first day, I came in the classroom, found a empty seat to sit down. This lecturer came in the classroom and introduced himself. Sitting there, listening to his words, analysing whether this lecturer is a killer or a grade giver until I heard that he introduced himself as a course coordinator. So I was like, well, if he is the course coordinator, then his grades would not change much, how much effort I gave in would not be graded down, that's not too bad!
THIS IS THE MISTAKE I MADE, WHERE THE NIGHTMARE STARTED.
I know you dont care about my experience, let's jump to my grade.
I performed well in presentations, but according to his words, my grade "overall grade has been greatly affected by both your writing 1 and writing 2".
For writing 1, this is an individual project, so I wrote the writing all by my own.
and for writing 2, it is a group project, we divide into different part for writing, my part is not long as I did a lot for the first presentation, I only have to write about 2 paragraphs.

==============================================

[Excellent, Very Good, Good, Satisfactory, Below Satisfactory, Poor, Very Poor]

Writing 1:
Substance & Synthesis: Satisfactory
Coherence: Below Satisfactory
Language: More than Satisfactory

This is the part where triggered me to write this review.

For substance & Synthesis, I read the whole 30-page case report for hours, finding clues inside, highlighting them, putting them in a doc file, and trying to make them relevant. This process already cost me almost 10 hours. But well, I got satisfactory; I don't know how Bruce marked my work on this. Maybe he used the number of references to mark student's work? But I also had 6 reference materials usedâ€”not just 3 or 4 references each page, but almost 8â€“10 for a fully written page. Mmm... Interesting..

For the Coherence part, the reason I got below satisfactory, is because I had used point form for matching the code ethics to the incident details, and divide the stakeholders one-by-one, I thought this would clearly show how they would match. And I saw no materials mentioning point-form is bad, I attended the lesson and Bruce emphasised we need to match the details to the code ethics one by one. However, after I got my grade, he said "Point form is greatly discouraged; and the connectivity between causes/issues could have been more interrelated. It is now, as it stands, ideas were truncated." I guess, blame me, I didn't ask him whether this is okay or that is okay on lesson.

For Language, this is the best part. I had not idea I would only got "more than Satisfatory", Bruce spotted some "mistakes" which I see no mistakes at all, and I have kept using them for my DSE, for my CORE1402/CORE1403 courses, I didn't know they are mistakes until now. I can't say more, let's just give you some ideas:
(1) "in lieu of a structural engineer" should be "instead of a structural engineer."
(2) "it is proposed that regulation should be implemented" should be "it is proposed to implement regulations."
(3) "Before the collapse, ..." should be "Prior to the collapse, ..."

I guess he is my leading light who could ameliorate my writing skills to another level. And, the essay is limited to 1000 words, I tried to reduce my word count during writing because I wrote too much.

===============================================

Writing 2:
Substance & Synthesis: Good
Coherence: More than Satisfactory
Language Use and Accuracy: More than Satisfactory

I don't have much to say about writing 2, since it is a group project, make sure you communicate well with your groupmates for Coherence, as my groupmates are deadline fighters, would not show up until the deadline day midnight/ morning, I guess you should find a friend with you.

===============================================

One more thing: this lesson also taught me telepathy.
"Detailed comments were provided to you on Canvas and now copied to the space below. Since the scores and comments were released on Oct 14 2023. No assignment review for Part 1 assessments would be accepted:"
The moment I am writing this review, I still can't see any comments on Canvas. I also asked my classmates, yes, nothing. I guess the course coordinator couldn't use canvas well.

P.S. All the presentation and report did not use GenAI

Final letter grade:
C+
===============================================
FYI:
English Writing: 5
Core 1402: B
all writing, mostly got Competent/Advanced ~ Advanced
Core 1403S: A,
half writing half video, writing part got Competent/Advanced ~ Advanced/Exceptional (Language)
reviews.comment_workload: Not much, until you need to do your assignments and presentation.

reviews.author: non-prof.benson
reviews.title: TLDR: Content is ok, grading is ok, workload is not so ok, and Eric is cool
reviews.comment_content:
This course consists of 2 parts:
1. Engineers and Social Responsibility
2. Engineers and Creativity

The 1st half would be focusing on engineer ethical issues, like "cost vs. safety" or "should I listen to my boss's stupid opinion" etc.
An engineer disaster case is assigned to each group, the case would be the topic of your analytical report and presentation. The task is to analyse the causes and ethical issues behind the disaster. Straight forward and not too difficult.

The 2nd half is about innovation, where you need to find an existing technology, review it, find the niche, and create a new thing that can solve the niche. This part requires a lot of researching, so be thoughtful to choose which area you want to study.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Eric is a pretty good instructor.
1. Encourage us to speak and discuss
2. He is also well-prepared for the lessons, I saw his teacher notes
have lots of stuff written on it.
3. Provide useful tips for our essay, like pointing out the inter-relationship between the causes in the disaster, and conditional sentences
4. Tell his stories if there's time remaining
reviews.comment_grading:
"Because they give me an A-, so I'm gonna give them an A for grading."

I was going to say that, but seriously, at the time of typing this review, I have only received the grades of:
1. 1st essay - Analytical Report (w/ comments)
2. 1st presentation
3. 2nd essay - Proposal Report (w/o comments)
So the grade of 2nd presentation and comments for my 2nd essay are missing. Come on Eric :(

I tried my best to follow the "Assessment Criteria" and the teaching from Eric. The grades I received in all assignment are nearly all "Very Good", with a final grade A-. Thus I suggest you doing so.
reviews.comment_workload:
Having suffered from Lang1002/1003 (or Core14xx) aka so-called "3 credit course", we all know Lang courses would never be 3 credits, but like 4-5 credits. Fortunately Lang2030 does not have insane workload (at least less than the previous 21-22 lang1003, f*ck that syllabus), but has a tight schedule as the deadlines are pretty close.

Assignment includes:
1. Two essays (pt.1: 900-1000w, pt.2 1000-1200w)
2. Two group presentations (14 mins for 3 people, 16 for 4 people)
3. Four practice tasks (3 short paragraph with range 100-150w, 1 mock presentation with 1 min for each person)
4. An 1-hour library workshop

The major problem is, you will have only 1 week after the deadline of the essay if you are the first to present. Even worse, if your groupmate(s) is/are freerider(s), you better pray to god for finishing  the PowerPoint within a week. Even even worse, the 1st presentation is within the midterm period, so GLHF!

reviews.author: C.C
reviews.title: Your hard work will not be rewarded
reviews.comment_content:
Content is fine, first your group conducts a case study on an engineering incident. In this part you need to analyze related ethical issues and try to convince people that those ethical issues may seriously undermine the company.

Then your group needs to come up with an engineering innovation e.g. a drone to deliver food, glasses to take note, language learning game etc. This part is fairly interesting and you need to walkthrough the whole process of how your innovation works. (this may help: in YouTube search "lang2030 presentation")

In both parts you need to write a report and hold presentation in class.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching and the attitude of instructor Bruce are fine. Also, he repeats key points that must be included in your report many times, so you will not fail this course easily.
reviews.comment_grading:
In short:
1. Your hard work will not be rewarded.
2. 0 grading transparency

I worked very hard for the group presentation e.g. making slides that are easy to understand, combining ideas & arranging rehearsals with group mates. I also thought throughly when writing the reports e.g. taking into account multiple perspectives and making sure all the key points are there.

When instructor Bruce gave us comments after the first presentation, I have learnt my mistakes and corrected them in the second presentation.

All these require huge amount of time and dedication, but in the end they slapped me with a

Grade: B

Why B? well I don't even know because this course has no transparency in terms of grading. They never release your report and presentation scores...  

For reference, I got A+,A- in other non common core courses with similar effort, so think twice before you put in serious effort here... I think I could've gotten B here in a much painless, easy way (and reallocate effort to other courses) :(
reviews.comment_workload: Mainly 2 reports and 2 presentations. Lecture attendance was not taken (which is good esp. in midterm weeks). The workload can be very high if you put in serious effort, but I don't recommend since it's not rewarding.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Ming makes the class very active, it's very rare for LANG classes based on my experience. As the contents of LANG courses are actually very boring, it's so lucky to meet an instructor who tell some jokes in the lectures and make you focused.
This kind of chilling atmosphere allows students to find new friends in class.
Besides, Ming really respect students own ideas and use fair way to decide the order of presentation by lucky draw.

reviews.author: An225 Mriya
reviews.title: Shooting Satellites
reviews.comment_content:
To engineering students, LANG2030 is your school-specific English course you'll need to take. And as a result, the course contents are more engineering-oriented, though its style is still with the typical LANG courses you experienced in 1002/1003 - i.e., water-blowing skills:
Unit 0: Engineers and identity (Introduction)
Unit 1: Engineers and social responsibility
Unit 2: Engineers and creativity

I have adequate reasons to believe that CLE compiled the course textbook without paying due regard to real-life engineering practicability. For example, an example in the textbook proposed using robots on horizontal rails to paint building exteriors. Sounds good? Another engineering student attending my session immediately stated the proposal suffered from serious structural integrity problem, and was in fact, chosen to be a negative example of engineering product in another course!
reviews.comment_teaching:
To my experience, Ellen Yik (Ping Chui) did her effort to maintain satisfactory learning atmosphere in her lessons. She also tried to encourage participation, such as organizing ad hoc mini-presentations related to course contents. Unfortunately, due to clashes with holidays and some additional sick leaves by Ellen, our teaching time ends up being quite cramped.

That said, as one will expect for a typical LANG course, the learning atmosphere is quite low. This is especially observable during f2f lessons. On one lesson, we were told to present something rather straightforward, such as doing presentations on junior-secondary English grammar in one lesson. While I do agree that those are common mistakes in writing, I simply don't think that presentation is the best way to practice this...
reviews.comment_grading:
Archived CLE content and grading page:
http://web.archive.org/web/20211223083945/https://cle.hkust.edu.hk/sites/default/files/2021-09/Course%20description-LANG%202030.pdf

Ethics essay: 5+5+5+5 (20%)
Ethics presentation: 6+5+5 (20%)
Invention proposal: 7+7+6+6 (20%)
Invention presentation: 6+5+5 (25%)
Vocabulary: Full (5%)
Completion of practice tasks and group work are also counted, with each of them consist of 5%.

From my experience, it seems that a practical design, even if a one purported to be, will help with your invention proposal grading. Also for the invention presentation, you will lose mark if you hold script, so one may want to practice more on your presentation part.

P.S.: the invention presentation consists of a Q&A section, with other students and the instructor will ask question of your invention. However, given by the course's learning environment, it is best not to ask too difficult questions, as everyone were aiming for a easy pass...

Ultimate grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
When compared to previous LANG1002/1003 (which usually only have 1-2 smaller speaking assignments), this course has a larger focus on presentation. One should also note that LANG2030 is less guided than the previous LANG1002/1003: you need to take charge of your own writing/invention project. There're no sub-assignments to guide you in LANG2030.

The individually submitted ethics essay and presentation require your group to work on a pre-determined engineering catastrophe, while the invention-related tasks require your group to "design" a invention and to promote it via an individually submitted proposal and a group presentation.

Why I quoted the design? As a LANG course (see Content part), the instructors don't care much about the practicability of your proposal. I've seen flying-taxis, underground logistics tubes, and much more inventions that looks best for pyramid/MLM fraudsters...

Speaking of workload, I consider it's similar to LANG1002/1003, except this time you're working with your groupmates in group assignments. Before that you were scavenging information for your essay, now that you're scavenging information for your group essays and projects.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Ummmm I would say Michael Tom is a relatively 'funny' teacher. (Although I can't search his name in UST space... :)))

Normal Teaching Time:

-he would always ask student questions when he thinks you are not paying attention
- he loves to use luckdraw to ask students to answer his tedious questions
- most importantly, he loves to laugh 9 students when he is in good mood

Nearly hand in assignment time:
- Sometimes he will provide us some examples that are in the textbook and will give some advice. However, as he really loves to 'chat' with students, these advice are given a few days before the deadline.

- But good news is, if you draft your writing earlier and sent to him for review, he will give useful comments and are willing to provide his hidden marking criteria

Overall, I think professor Michael Tom is a smart teacher. Hopefully not to see any students fall into his trap again.

reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is kinda a lot comparing to other classes. The most workload periods are when you have to hand in the assignments. Especially when you do the innovation project, Michael will need you to submit a reading according to your topic in canvas every week. This was very chur as our group have to discuss our topics and powerpoints while have to handle the practice task on canvas.

Besides the assignment hand in period, we need to review the course materials about next lesson.

The above are the workloads in normal times. For the projects, I think every classes are the same.

1. Analytical report
- 700-800words
- have to do a case study
- research on the case and provide ethical perspective.
- usually background, ethical issue and conclusion.
- have to do by our own.

2. Innovation proposal report
- have introduction, literature review, technical description, feasibility & benefits and conclusion 5 parts.
- 1000-1200words

3. Group presentation
- Q&A section but not graded
- around 5 mins for case analysis, 12-14mins for innovation presentation.
- need to cooperate with groupmates, better find good one, not free riders.

Overall, on9 compulsory course and will waste your time.

reviews.comment_workload:
Because its summer sem, there are 3 lessons per week and each lesson is 2 hr 50 mins. A bit chur but can still handle if there is no free-rider in your group.

1. Group presentation (ethical issue)
- 4 people in a group (in fall/spring sem should be 3)
- each student should present less than 5 minutes
- study a case and analyze the ethical issue invovled
- cases are provided just choose one from it

2. Analytical report
- 700 to 800 words
- content is the same as the case study presentation, so you don't have to search many things as you already did that in the presentation
- write on your own, this is not a group work

3. Group presentation (Innovation)
- basic requirements are same with the previous presentation
- think of an innovation and introduce it
- workload depends on your innovation (whether it is easy to talk about)

4. Innovation report
- 1000 to 1200 words
- make your presentation into an essay, though the structure is different
- write on your own, this is not a group work

5. 4 practice tasks
- very easy so I don't count it a workload

6. VOLT test
- same as above

The overall workload is light as I got good groupmates.

reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy indeed.

Two â€œgroups of assessmentsâ€ throughout the semester.

Each group consists of a writing task and a speaking task. The speaking tasks are even group works.

The due dates on the 1st writing and 1st speaking overlapped with midterm exams of many other courses; while the 2nd writing and 2nd speaking overlapped with many final course projects.

reviews.author: agoti
reviews.title: It's possible to get A/A+
reviews.comment_content:
As described, this is basically a LANG course with a bit more focus on Engineering. One has to write (and present) an ethical analysis for an engineering disaster, and another proposal for an innovation.

Other than that, the most useful aspect of the course is probably just the formatting and guidelines for writing reports, under the context of engineering (IEEE format, technical description). There's nothing particularly significant about language use (the instructor did put an emphasis on conditional tense and some sentence structures), probably since those are assumed to be learnt in LANG1002/1003
reviews.comment_teaching:
Probably because of zoom, the teaching style is somewhat awkward. With less actual things to teach in each lesson, about half of the lesson time is spent on breakout group discussions and oral summary from those groups. If you are grouped with people who you are familiar with (or are willing to talk), you might do fine. Otherwise, there might be a lot more awkward silences than one might desire.

There are also out-of-class activities like paragraph writing practices and reading/video materials, but most of them aren't even checked afterwards (at least in class)
reviews.comment_grading: Contrary to previous reviews, it turned out that A+ is entirely possible and not "reserved for the H course". It might be based on tutor (and their impression of you), however, given how Edward mentioned that it is his first time teaching this course (or sth similar)
reviews.comment_workload:
Your feeling of the workload may vary depending on the last LANG stream, and the respective tutors for this and the previous course.

In my case, we were given some writing/reading (video-watching) tasks every 2 or so lessons, which again weren't that strictly checked. The group project (essay and video presentation) in turn needs a lot more active participation out-of-class, but the "group" part may be a blessing or a curse depending on your groupmate's willingness to participate.
If you have groupmates that are active enough, the work should be well distributed and manageable. (esp. important for innovation, there's no way you can handle that yourself in the given time)

reviews.author: {Curly Braces}
reviews.title: Broken Grading
reviews.comment_content:
Topic 1 - Engineering Ethics
Basically, it is talking about ethical issues in engineering. Students are instructed to split into groups and analyze an ethical issue given.

Topic 2 - Engineering Innovation
In this topic, we are going to devise an invention and present it in both written and verbal manner.

In my opinion, these topics are fair. Some student may found topic 1 boring, but it is quite interesting in terms of how engineers failed to strike a balance between profit and safety, and lead to disaster at last.
For topic 2, I would say it is a topic that we are more likely to touch in the future for engineering students, but the problem is that new inventions are happening every now and then, the real "innovative" inventions are actually hard to make one. At least in my section, most of the students' ideas are actually already existed.
reviews.comment_teaching: Fair. I think it is generally quite standard.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
Part 1 - Engineering Ethics
   Group Presentation + Seminar discussion on Engineering Ethics Issue - 20%
   Analytical Report on Engineering Ethics Issue - 20%

Part 2 - Engineering Innovation
   Group Presentation of Proposal on Engineering Innovation - 20%
   Proposal Report on Engineering Innovation - 25%

Miscellaneous
   VOLT Vocab Tests - 5%
   Group Work for Group presentations - 5%
   Attendance, Out-of-class Activities - 5%

The grading is actually quite mindblowing. I got on average 5 on all tasks, and done most of the miscellaneous tasks, and end up with a B-.
Back in LANG1002/1003, this score level should be able to let you obtain B/B+, but sorry, this is a 2000-level LANG course!
reviews.comment_workload:
Depends on two things:
1. Your teammate
2. Difficulty in researching on your invention

The first factor shouldn't be a big problem in this course since teamwork is also considered in the grade.
For the second one, it is a more major factor since you have to make a balance on originality and existing technology of your invention.

Not only that, remind that you have to do 2 writing task and speaking tasks throughout the course!

reviews.author: SQ Flyer
reviews.title: Nice teaching with simplified assessment during pandemic åˆç†Grading
reviews.comment_content:
LANG 2030 is a language course specifically designed for Year 2 engineering students. It comprises with two parts, engineering ethics and engineering innovation.

1. Engineering ethics
Each group (3 students) is assigned with an engineering ethical case and work on an individual analytical report(700 words) and a group presentation (max 15 mins), investigating the causes and development of an engineering disaster, its relevant ethical issue and misconducts, and provide suggestions and recommendations.

2. Engineering innovation
Propose an innovative engineering idea/technology with an individual report (1000-1200 words) and a group proposal presentation (15 mins), with Q&A session during classes.  

During classes, the tutor would provide guidance on the language features for presenting the ideas in the report and the presentation.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr Bruce Ma is a really nice guy who prepares useful lesson materials and provides exercises and relevant demonstration for the assigned tasks.

For the writing tasks, not only he would discuss the structure and organization, but he focuses on how to deliver ideas with proper language features and vocabularies precisely. He would simply demonstrate to us. So no worry if you have doubts on how to present the writings. He did a really nice job.

Sometimes he shares his teaching experiences with us and some fun facts about him. So the overall class atmosphere is fine even classes are conducted via Zoom this semester.
reviews.comment_grading:
The assessment rubics this semester is different from previous semesters due to the pandemic. I would say the assessments are simplified.

Analytical Report 20%
Ethical Case Presentation 20%
Proposal Report 25%
Proposal Presentation 20%
After-class Vocabulary self practices 5% (just finish all then full mark)
Group Work for Part 1/2 on Canvas 5% (just completed all then fine)
Participation (Attendance, assigned Canvas discussion etc) 5%

Grading:
Analytical Report 6666
Ethical Case Presentation 5655
Vocab Test Full Mark
Group Work Full Mark

Overall B+
I think students have to get some 6 for speaking assessment in order to get A-Range.
But it's still reasonable grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is a bit heavy for some tasks, especially the proposal report which you need to make up a topic with your group-mates and conduct some research before actually writing. The report requires at least a 1000 word so better start writing early.

The analytical report topic is assigned by your tutor. My assigned topic is Tianjin Explosion, where you are provided with some background information and you can search some additional materials for the writing. Study some of the relevant ethical codes from HKIE and WFEO.

The presentations are video-taped after-class and you can make the arrangements with your group-mates.

You are also required to complete 10 after class vocabulary practice on VOLT and some assigned discussions for the out of class activities and the assessment group work on Canvas.

reviews.author: Tommy Li
reviews.title: Your tutor, your fate
reviews.comment_content:
You won't expect interesting content in a LANG course, right?

This course focuses on technical writing and speaking. It is a (mostly, technically not) project-based course which students are divided into groups for two small projects. Both parts consist a writing assessment (individual) and a speaking assessment (group).

The first part of the course is about analyzing ethical issues. Each group is given an ethical case to conduct a research. Causes and their ethical implications of the case have to be analysed. The individual writing and group presentation may share the same content.

The second part of the course is about presenting an innovation. Each group have to come up with a new tech product and write up a proposal. Research has to be done to investigate the product's feasibility and the potential benefits.

However, IMO the content is not that important. The good thing is you will meet some new friends deadline fighting with you for the projects. :)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Rosie is the most passionate tutor/lecturer that I have ever seen.

She is a extremely organized tutor. The schedule was very well managed. While she had 5 classes this semester, she still offered lots of consultation slots for us. She sent lots of email to remind you about the deadlines, and there are lots of supplementary info that helps you with your assignments. What's more, her speed in replying emails is insane! She will tell you when she can reply back even she is not free. lol

She gave extremely detailed feedback on all the assignments. Her comments sometimes are even longer than our work! #adore# Although some of our work are done poorly, she did not discourage us. Instead, she put some focus on the thing we did well and gave constructive feedback to help us improve.

She is a very kind-hearted tutor. For the part 2 assignments, most of us are distracted by the incident and were busy with other subjects. So, she got in touch with the coordinators and asked for deadline extension just for our class. (Extended by 2 days as a result.) I remember once my teammate did not prepare well for the consultation. She did not blame my teammate, and even held an additional consultation just for him!

I am extremely impressed by how much effort Rosie had put in this course. She might not be the best tutor for English (don't get me wrong, she taught pretty good!) but definitely is the nicest tutor. Definitely recommended.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not as bad as other reviews claimed. Rosie is also pretty lenient for grading the assignments. The grade quite depends on how the curve is adjusted among different classes and how your tutor grades you. It turns out to be similar to LANG 1002 which mostly 5s and a few 6s yield an A- (for my class).

Analytical Report: 4.5 5 4.5 5
Ethical Presentation: 5 5 4.5
Proposal Report: 5.5 5.5 6 6
TechVention Presentation: 5 6 5.5
Vocab test: 11/15
Overall: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is a little bit more than an average course. Aside from the four standard writing and speaking assessments, we have to complete canvas writings and vocabulary tests. There may be additional out-of-class exercises from the course book (depends on tutor).

Additionally, you have to reserve time for lots of project meetings. Most likely, you need to allocate one or two hours weekly for project meetings and consultations. A good communication among your group is quite essential in this course.

Really glad to have a tutor that would extend the deadly deadlines.

reviews.author: rcelis
reviews.comment_content:
2 Essays(Case investigation and Proposal)
2 Group presentations
3 Vocab tests
Attendance needed
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is quite ok when giving instructions. Quite boring. Proposal for the innovative design is more fun. Better not to join 0900 am class or you will likely fall asleep.
reviews.comment_grading: Normal English course grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not too heavy workload if you are not the deadline fighter.
Proposal for the innovative design is sorta confusing when doing it. You do not need to do the prototype for this. (ofz this is an English course!) However, you need to state what kinda technology you would use in your innovation and feasibility. What I think is: I did not make it in reality either, how could I know the feasibility. :D But anyway, this improves your make-up story(blow water) technique.

reviews.author: Annioto
reviews.title: Chem 1004
reviews.comment_content:
Secondary school Chem stuff
CHEM1004 is an introductory course provided for students who have never taken a chemistry course but would like to learn what chemistry is and how it may affect the world we live in. Course objectives are as follows:
1. Introduce basic concepts of Chemistry.
2. Connect Chemistry with everyday life and modern technology.
3. Explain the importance of Chemistry in the environment, medicine, and daily life.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is good.
reviews.comment_grading:
The final grade for the course will be consisted of:
10 %from the Online Quizzes
30 %from the Study Project
60 %from the final Examination
The course is graded from A+ to F. An F grade will not earn you credits for the course.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload in this course is ok.

reviews.author: chpoonag
reviews.title: No matter how hard you try, A/A+'s are reserved for LANG 2030H.
reviews.comment_content:
This course is divided into 2 parts:
1. Engineering Ethics
You have 2 tasks to do. First is writing an essay on an engineering ethics issue. Some cases are provided and you have to work on 1 of the cases assigned by the tutor. Second is presenting the issue in groups of 3 to 4 in front of your classmates.

Due to the presentation, you should be divided into groups prior to the essay task, and so your groupmates and you will be writing about the same case. Note that the case is the same but the content in your own essay may differ from theirs.

As for the presentation, it will be 1-2 weeks after the submission of the essay. Only 1 slide per group member is allowed in THIS presentation, and our tutor emphasized the need for animation in the slide.

Personally, it was so hard at that time as the presentation is within the midterm period.

2. Proposal Report
In this part, 2 tasks are given. One is an individual proposal report of an innovation. The subsequent task is a presentation in groups of 3 to 4.

Similarly, the idea in the report should be similar to the one to be presented, yet the details can differ from your groupmates (for example, some components/functions may be added/removed). The technology needed should be based on existing technology but the PRODUCT should be new. This is a difficult part for most of us (why don't companies just adopt our "new" ideas if ours are better?). So, our tutor suggested just adding some new components/functions on an existing product. In my opinion, if you really cannot think of a genuinely new product, make sure your tutor does not know about its existence. My idea was initially just a speed bump using non-Newtonian fluid, and the tutor originally did not know that and he approved that.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Mr Yuen is a patient, responsive and serious teacher. You can ask him from the usage of a specific word to the writing style of your essay. Emails were replied within 1 day after sending.

You can probably learn as much as you would like to from him.
reviews.comment_grading:
I knew that most of us in Mr Yuen's class mainly got at least 5's in most of the assignments.

Yet, the grading in this course is just fair.
As seen in the subtitle, "no matter how hard you try, A/A+'s are reserved for LANG 2030H." This should be attributable to expectations of our performances, similar to LANG 1002/1003. If you are the one who studied LANG 1002S and LANG 1003A, you should have the experience that you can easily get an A in the A stream classes.

I did really pay a lot of effort on the reports and I think I can secure an A- and possibly an A.
Finally, I really got A-, same as those who got some 5 and 6 in their assignments.

Some data:
Part 1
Report: 6556
Presentation: 666
Part 2
Report: 7667
Presentation: 766

Vocabulary test 1: 12/15
Vocabulary test 2: 13/15
Vocabulary test 3: 13/15
Participation: ?/5

Total: 86% (assume participation 4 out of 5)

One of my friends got some 5 and 6 and got A- as well.
reviews.comment_workload:
Without final exams, the workload during the final exam period was greatly reduced.

However, as mentioned, one presentation is in midterm exam period. Therefore, it may be hard for some people who have their presentation on the same day as other courses' midterm exam(s).

Also, if you want to secure an A- or B+, make sure you use different synonyms in your essays and sentence structures (eg inversion, conditional sentences, etc). You may want to have a list to see what types of sentence structures you have not yet utilized. Besides, coherence is a big issue. Critically judge on your work. You may let your tutor take a glance on it first.


As for the presentations, I heard that some tutors did not allow any cue cards. Don't worry with that in Yuen's classes. Some of us just printed the whole script out or brought a mobile during presentations. Just make sure you don't rely on it or you would get at most 4 in communication skills.

reviews.author: STT
reviews.comment_content:
First part will be about engineering ethics
Second part will be about an innovative design of your own.

Basically the instructor teaches according to the content of the book, but only parts where he shows and guides you how the reports and presentations should be done are useful, others are quite boring(like engineering ethics) and didn't find it specifically useful for learning engineering-related English.
reviews.comment_teaching: Instructor do gave some useful vocabulary and stressed some points to show us how to score higher marks. You can really feel that he wanted to teach us something useful.
reviews.comment_grading:
-Attendance
-3 vocab test (question are made in a way that are kind of related to engineering)
-2 reports
-2 presentation

First report
5 5 5
Instructor was strict on this one, as he said he once gave students higher marks and the marks were eventually adjusted because he was considered being too lenient.

First presentation
7 6 6
If you really search for some useful content(not wasting time) and practice a bit, you will find yourself already doing better than others on class as they usually take little time to prepare.
Other marks were not provided to us
Got A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Compared to some engineering course which only required you to hand in hw and calculate maths(like some MECH course), writing reports and preparing presentation will spend you much more time.
If you want to get higher grade, you will definitely need to spend more time to do research, adjust and proofread your report, and practise your presentation with your classmate.
Also pls pls pls find good students to form groups for tasks.

reviews.author: Qoooooooo

Just the contents on the text book
not related to the grade

But have two reports and two 15-minute group presentations to do, so the group-mates are really important( allowed to choose group mates for the second presentation)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very good
Taught a lot about how to write the report and do the presentation, really useful
Also let us do homework in class and will remind you to post your paragraph on canvas if you forgot.
She really tried to make the class a more pleasant one.
reviews.comment_grading:
attendance( including attendance in class and writing paragraphs on canvas)
three vocabulary tests
two reports and two presentations

got 12/15 in the first vocab test, 12/15 for the second one and 14/15 for the third one
forgot the report marks
6 6 6 for the first presentation( the first 6 is the group mark)
7 7 7 for the second presentation
got A
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is acceptable, maybe a little heavy for someone not interested in writing.
Usually take a whole afternoon to finish the report and several days to get familiar with the presentation content.
But you have to work really hard if you want to get an A- or above

so-so

teach with seriousness

turns out to be quite surprising
got ten 5s and two 6s
vocab quizzes 41/45 in total
-> A-

Heavy but in some sense meaningless workload

two group presentations
3 vocab quizzes
several out-of-class writings

reviews.comment_content:
Just like LANG1002/1003, you have to buy a textbook and the tutor will follow activities insides. The course is divided into 2 parts:
1. Engineers and Social Responsibility
2. Engineers and Creativity

The only useful content in the whole of the semester was the introduction of IEEE citations, which you will use this citation style to write your analytical and proposal report.

There is also a Library workshop you are required to attend.
reviews.comment_teaching: Elaine is a nice tutor and she always holds some group activities during the lessons, therefore it is not boring at all. Before the start  of each lesson, she will chat with us in order to let us relax and know more about us.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grade is better compare with LANG1003:

Analytical Report (20%):                  5, 5, 5, 4
Seminar Presentation (20%):          5, 5, 6
Proposal Report (20%):                   5, 5, 5, 5
Proposal Presentation (20%):          5, 5, 6
Vocabulary Quizzes x3 (15%):        ~70% Correct
Participation (5%):                          Unknown

Final Grade: B
reviews.comment_workload:
Apart from the assignment, there are also several out-of class exercise such as canvas discussion or other stuffs given by her. Therefore the workload is quite heavy if you didn't manage your time well, especially when the deadlines of graded assignment crashed with other major courses.

You can choose your group mates for your assignment, therefore choose your group mates wisely!
